stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 11th course, an oil rig level, focusing on a mission where the player messes with Koopa workers. Key activities included implementing a glass-breaking mechanic, designing and modeling a Wiggler overseer character with Zeina, and deciding to cut a planned mission objective. He also briefly showcased and discussed a separate side project, 'Only Up 64'.

development_findings.summary: Kaze reflected on his growth as a designer, noting he now dedicates significantly more time to the design phase upfront compared to his process on previous projects like 'Last Impact'.
development_findings.quote: when I made last impact i spent like maybe... 5% of the time designing and like 95% of the time working but i should have been spending at least 20% of the time designing

development_findings.summary: To create a glass-shattering effect, Kaze opted to hard-code the animation of two large pieces falling away, faking the physics to avoid the complexity and performance cost of a real simulation.
development_findings.quote: we're just gonna fake it so we don't actually have to write a physics simulation

development_findings.summary: Kaze cut a planned mission objective involving an oil slick because he deemed it too unintuitive and not comedic enough, choosing to reduce the mission to four objectives instead of five.
development_findings.quote: This is bad because it's just so cryptic to just kick over the random oil barrel. Who would think to do that?

development_findings.summary: A creative idea to put hard hats on each segment of a Wiggler was scrapped after Kaze realized it exceeded the polygon budget, forcing a design simplification to maintain performance.
development_findings.quote: a thousand triangles is too much. Can't waste my polygon budget like that.

development_findings.summary: A secret Wing Cap was added to the level as a fun bonus, but Kaze acknowledged it creates the problem of players flying to unloaded areas, which will likely be solved with an invisible wall.
Kaze developed a side-project ROM hack, 'Only Up 64', for a competition. It features a custom anti-savestate mechanism that detects memory desynchronization to prevent cheating.

The dialogue for the Koopas whose glass is shattered was written to reflect their worker status, with lines like 'There goes this year's salary' and concerns about the cost coming out of their paycheck.

context_findings.summary: Kaze strongly prefers working from home, finding the idea of working in a physical office building to be awful.
context_findings.quote: I don't want to work in a physical building. That sounds very awful for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for 2D platformers, particularly when modern controllers with analog sticks are forced to emulate an 8-directional D-pad, which he considers an archaic control scheme.
context_findings.quote: I watched the intro cutscene and then I touched the control stick and I instantly stopped playing the game because the control stick was an emulated d-pad.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote about shaving his head in Germany and being mistaken for a Nazi, which is a reason he is reluctant to do it again.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I did that once and everyone thought I was being a Nazi because I was bald. And usually when you're bald in German, people think you're being a Nazi.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works professionally as a programmer for Gears for Breakfast, the developers of 'A Hat in Time', and is under an NDA regarding their current project.
Kaze advocates for a hybrid control scheme using a controller in the left hand for analog movement and a mouse in the right hand for precise aiming, believing it to be the optimal setup for shooters.
context_findings.quote: I think controller plus mouse is the future.

biobak.summary: Biobak was not present during the stream, but Kaze jokingly suggested making a controversial Andrew Tate song into 'the Biobak theme song'.

badub.summary: Badub is creating the soundtrack for the oil rig level. Kaze played a work-in-progress version and commented that it has 'pretty good ideas'.

zeina.summary: Zeina worked on animations for a baby penguin character, including a walk and dive, and was instructed by Kaze to close a hole in the 3D model's neck.
Zeina acknowledged that animating the new, multi-segmented Wiggler character will be very challenging, even more so than animating Bowser.
zeina.quote: I thought Bowser was difficult enough, this is gonna be even worse.

zeina.summary: Zeina provided real-time feedback on the Wiggler's design, suggesting its boots should be rubber and have a larger cuff to fit the oil rig worker theme.
Zeina described her role on the project as helping with animations and any other tasks Kaze requires.
zeina.quote: I'm just helping out with animations. And anything else that he needs.

key_stories.title: Faking the Physics of Shattering Glass
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a glass-breaking effect for an interactive object. After considering and rejecting more complex solutions like particles or many pre-cut pieces due to workload and aesthetic concerns, he opted for a simple, efficient solution: faking the physics by animating two large pieces of glass falling away.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a satisfying glass-shattering effect for a level interaction without a complex physics simulation or an unreasonable amount of modeling work.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed several options, including 2D particles (rejected as unfitting for sharp glass) and breaking the model into many small, pre-determined pieces (rejected as too much manual work).
key_stories.outcome: He decided to split the glass model into just two pieces and create a hard-coded, faked physics animation where they fall over and spin away. This provided a good-enough visual with minimal technical overhead and development time.
key_stories.key_quote: we're just gonna fake it so we don't actually have to write a physics simulation

key_stories.title: Scrapping the Fifth Troll
key_stories.summary: Kaze's mission design required five funny interactions, but he felt the fifth idea (an oil slick) was unintuitive. He chose to cut the weak link and improve the mission's structure by adding a Wiggler overseer, demonstrating his willingness to prioritize quality and clarity over quantity.
key_stories.challenge: The mission design called for five ways to mess with the Koopa workers, but the fifth idea felt weak and unintuitive.
key_stories.process: The proposed idea was for the player to kick an oil barrel, creating a slick that would cause a worker to slip. Kaze evaluated this and concluded it was too cryptic for the player to discover and the comedic payoff wasn't worth the potential confusion.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to cut the fifth interaction entirely, reducing the objective to four. To provide a clear mission conclusion, he conceived of a new Wiggler overseer character who would react to the player's progress and spawn the star.
key_stories.key_quote: I think kicking the oil barrel is not intuitive and also that's not very funny. So I'm not really a fan of that.

key_stories.title: The Wiggler Overseer's Polygon Budget
key_stories.summary: While designing a Wiggler character, Kaze and Zeina's creative idea to put a hard hat on each body segment proved too polygon-heavy for the N64. This forced them to compromise the humorous design, removing the extra hats and simplifying the model to meet technical constraints.
key_stories.challenge: To create a unique Wiggler character to act as an overseer for the level's mission, but the initial creative ideas were too graphically intensive for the N64.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Zeina brainstormed making the Wiggler an oil rig worker with boots and a hard hat. Kaze had the humorous idea to put a tiny hard hat on each of the Wiggler's body segments, but upon implementation, he realized the hats alone added over 240 polygons.
key_stories.outcome: The extra hats were deemed too costly for the polygon budget and were removed. Kaze further optimized the model by simplifying the boots and removing the inside faces of the main helmet, bringing the polygon count down to a more manageable level.
key_stories.key_quote: a thousand triangles is too much. Can't waste my polygon budget like that.
